name: Introduction to MongoDB Atlas, the Developer Data Platform

caption.name: Introduction to MongoDB Atlas, the Developer Data Platform
caption.text:
1
00:00:00,510 --> 00:00:01,720
Welcome back, team.

2
00:00:01,720 --> 00:00:03,450
In this video,
we'll introduce you

3
00:00:03,450 --> 00:00:06,930
to MongoDB Atlas, our developer
data platform, and how

4
00:00:06,930 --> 00:00:09,600
it makes working with data
easy for a wide variety

5
00:00:09,600 --> 00:00:10,830
of applications.

6
00:00:10,830 --> 00:00:13,440
We'll also cover the
components of the platform that

7
00:00:13,440 --> 00:00:16,530
address common requirements
of modern applications.

8
00:00:16,530 --> 00:00:18,720
This means there's
less need to introduce

9
00:00:18,720 --> 00:00:21,750
additional technologies that
may complicate your development

10
00:00:21,750 --> 00:00:23,260
process.

11
00:00:23,260 --> 00:00:25,230
Let's begin by reviewing
how your data is

12
00:00:25,230 --> 00:00:27,120
stored in MongoDB Atlas.

13
00:00:27,120 --> 00:00:30,330
Atlas is our comprehensive
developer data platform.

14
00:00:30,330 --> 00:00:34,170
At its core is Atlas database,
our database as a service.

15
00:00:34,170 --> 00:00:36,300
This means that when
you're using Atlas,

16
00:00:36,300 --> 00:00:38,640
you don't need to
manage MongoDB yourself.

17
00:00:38,640 --> 00:00:41,520
Instead, Atlas will manage
the database for you

18
00:00:41,520 --> 00:00:44,760
and handle all of the lifecycle
details behind the scenes.

19
00:00:44,760 --> 00:00:47,040
When using Atlas, your
database deployments

20
00:00:47,040 --> 00:00:49,590
have built-in replication,
or what MongoDB

21
00:00:49,590 --> 00:00:51,640
refers to as a replica set.

22
00:00:51,640 --> 00:00:53,340
This means that
your data is stored

23
00:00:53,340 --> 00:00:56,940
on more than one server, which
is a core tenet of MongoDB.

24
00:00:56,940 --> 00:00:59,370
This ensures both
data redundancy,

25
00:00:59,370 --> 00:01:01,830
and that your data will
be available in the event

26
00:01:01,830 --> 00:01:03,480
of a server failure.

27
00:01:03,480 --> 00:01:06,300
In Atlas, there are two types
of database deployments--

28
00:01:06,300 --> 00:01:09,210
serverless instances
and clusters.

29
00:01:09,210 --> 00:01:11,460
A serverless instance
scales on demand

30
00:01:11,460 --> 00:01:14,640
and only charges you for
the resources that you use.

31
00:01:14,640 --> 00:01:17,070
Serverless instances
are a great option

32
00:01:17,070 --> 00:01:20,370
for applications with highly
variable or sparse workloads

33
00:01:20,370 --> 00:01:21,180
over time.

34
00:01:21,180 --> 00:01:22,860
This is a much
simpler choice if you

35
00:01:22,860 --> 00:01:24,300
don't know what
hardware you need,

36
00:01:24,300 --> 00:01:26,910
or if you just want to use
a serverless architecture

37
00:01:26,910 --> 00:01:28,230
in general.

38
00:01:28,230 --> 00:01:31,690
A cluster is several MongoDB
servers working together.

39
00:01:31,690 --> 00:01:35,520
There are two cluster
options, shared and dedicated.

40
00:01:35,520 --> 00:01:38,310
Shared clusters are smaller
and include a free tier

41
00:01:38,310 --> 00:01:41,100
option, which is a great way
to get started with Atlas.

42
00:01:41,100 --> 00:01:44,020
It has over 100,000 new
deployments per month.

43
00:01:44,020 --> 00:01:46,510
So rest assured that if
you choose this option,

44
00:01:46,510 --> 00:01:49,800
you can run your small
projects on it indefinitely.

45
00:01:49,800 --> 00:01:52,500
Finally, dedicated
clusters are larger

46
00:01:52,500 --> 00:01:55,110
dedicated resources
and can be customized

47
00:01:55,110 --> 00:01:56,770
to your specific needs.

48
00:01:56,770 --> 00:02:00,150
There are options for both low
and high traffic applications

49
00:02:00,150 --> 00:02:02,730
that have cluster scaling
enabled by default,

50
00:02:02,730 --> 00:02:05,260
as well as enhanced
security features.

51
00:02:05,260 --> 00:02:08,820
This is the preferred choice
for production workloads.

52
00:02:08,820 --> 00:02:10,680
When deploying your
cluster on Atlas,

53
00:02:10,680 --> 00:02:13,300
you can choose from a
number of cloud providers,

54
00:02:13,300 --> 00:02:16,680
including AWS, Google
Cloud, and Microsoft Azure,

55
00:02:16,680 --> 00:02:19,200
in over 100 geographic regions.

56
00:02:19,200 --> 00:02:22,290
You can deploy globally across
multiple regions or even

57
00:02:22,290 --> 00:02:23,550
multiple clouds.

58
00:02:23,550 --> 00:02:26,220
As your needs change,
so can your cluster.

59
00:02:26,220 --> 00:02:29,310
You always have the option
to change your scaling tier,

60
00:02:29,310 --> 00:02:31,320
region, or cloud provider.

61
00:02:31,320 --> 00:02:35,520
Atlas will make these changes
for you without any downtime.

62
00:02:35,520 --> 00:02:38,400
Atlas includes operational
insights and backups

63
00:02:38,400 --> 00:02:40,080
with point-in-time restore.

64
00:02:40,080 --> 00:02:43,140
It also has capabilities
useful for later stages

65
00:02:43,140 --> 00:02:45,000
of the lifecycle,
like built-in data

66
00:02:45,000 --> 00:02:46,950
tiering with online archive.

67
00:02:46,950 --> 00:02:49,170
You can learn more
about online archive

68
00:02:49,170 --> 00:02:51,760
in one of our advanced
courses when you're ready.

69
00:02:51,760 --> 00:02:54,000
You can also manage
everything from the command

70
00:02:54,000 --> 00:02:58,620
line using the Atlas CLI
or the administration API.

71
00:02:58,620 --> 00:03:02,430
MongoDB Atlas is more than
just a database as a service.

72
00:03:02,430 --> 00:03:05,230
It's a comprehensive
developer data platform.

73
00:03:05,230 --> 00:03:08,400
It provides an integrated
suite of products and services

74
00:03:08,400 --> 00:03:10,920
that developers can use
to build applications

75
00:03:10,920 --> 00:03:13,030
faster than ever before.

76
00:03:13,030 --> 00:03:15,510
Let's quickly discuss
some of the other services

77
00:03:15,510 --> 00:03:17,460
available in Atlas.

78
00:03:17,460 --> 00:03:20,460
Atlas Search enables you to
build rich search experiences

79
00:03:20,460 --> 00:03:22,170
on top of your
data in the cloud.

80
00:03:22,170 --> 00:03:24,390
There's no need for a
separate search engine.

81
00:03:24,390 --> 00:03:26,130
You can actually
access everything

82
00:03:26,130 --> 00:03:29,550
from MongoDB's aggregation
query interface simply

83
00:03:29,550 --> 00:03:31,560
by using the search operator.

84
00:03:31,560 --> 00:03:33,840
Atlas device sync
allows you to keep data

85
00:03:33,840 --> 00:03:37,690
in sync between the cloud and
mobile or other edge devices.

86
00:03:37,690 --> 00:03:41,160
This means that you can deliver
rich, always-on experiences

87
00:03:41,160 --> 00:03:42,510
anywhere.

88
00:03:42,510 --> 00:03:45,120
Atlas Data Lake lets you
automatically extract

89
00:03:45,120 --> 00:03:49,080
data from your Atlas databases
to your own low cost, fully

90
00:03:49,080 --> 00:03:51,030
managed data lake environment.

91
00:03:51,030 --> 00:03:53,130
Our Data Lake uses
a format that's

92
00:03:53,130 --> 00:03:56,020
optimized for
analytical queries.

93
00:03:56,020 --> 00:04:00,460
Atlas Data Federation allows you
to seamlessly query, transform,

94
00:04:00,460 --> 00:04:04,450
aggregate, and write data from
Atlas databases, Atlas Data

95
00:04:04,450 --> 00:04:08,470
Lakes, or your own cloud
object storage environments.

96
00:04:08,470 --> 00:04:12,050
Atlas Charts is a built-in
data visualization tool.

97
00:04:12,050 --> 00:04:15,160
It allows you to easily
create, share, and embed

98
00:04:15,160 --> 00:04:19,430
rich dashboards built from
your own data in the cloud.

99
00:04:19,430 --> 00:04:22,780
Finally, Atlas App Services
offers a set of capabilities

100
00:04:22,780 --> 00:04:24,580
that allow you to build faster.

101
00:04:24,580 --> 00:04:26,920
It includes a data
API, which enables

102
00:04:26,920 --> 00:04:28,870
you to read and
write data in Atlas

103
00:04:28,870 --> 00:04:31,210
with standard HTTPS requests.

104
00:04:31,210 --> 00:04:34,570
It also includes a
GraphQL API, functions,

105
00:04:34,570 --> 00:04:37,840
and triggers to enable you
to easily create applications

106
00:04:37,840 --> 00:04:40,570
with event-driven architectures.

107
00:04:40,570 --> 00:04:44,140
Our engineers work hard to build
MongoDB Atlas, our developer

108
00:04:44,140 --> 00:04:46,420
data platform, with
MongoDB's mission

109
00:04:46,420 --> 00:04:50,920
in mind to empower innovators to
create, transform, and disrupt

110
00:04:50,920 --> 00:04:54,820
industries by unleashing the
power of software and data.

111
00:04:54,820 --> 00:04:57,670
We look forward to seeing what
you build with our developer

112
00:04:57,670 --> 00:04:59,460
data platform.

name: Intro to MongoDB: Unit 1: Lesson 2: Creating and Deploying an Atlas Cluster

caption.name: Intro to MongoDB: Unit 1: Lesson 2: Creating and Deploying an Atlas Cluster
caption.text:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:01,750
Welcome back, team.

2
00:00:01,750 --> 00:00:04,170
In this video, we'll
set up an Atlas account,

3
00:00:04,170 --> 00:00:07,200
deploy an Atlas cluster,
and use the Data Explorer

4
00:00:07,200 --> 00:00:10,270
to load and view sample data.

5
00:00:10,270 --> 00:00:13,680
Let's go ahead and sign up for
a new account on MongoDB Atlas.

6
00:00:13,680 --> 00:00:17,160
To do so, first, we'll go
to the MongoDB home page.

7
00:00:17,160 --> 00:00:21,948
In the upper right-hand corner,
you'll see the Try Free button.

8
00:00:21,948 --> 00:00:23,490
Go ahead and click
on that, and it'll

9
00:00:23,490 --> 00:00:25,320
bring you to a Sign
Up page in which you

10
00:00:25,320 --> 00:00:28,350
can fill out this form in
order to get a new account.

11
00:00:28,350 --> 00:00:30,490
If you have a Gmail,
at the bottom,

12
00:00:30,490 --> 00:00:33,842
you'll also find a Sign up
with Google button as well.

13
00:00:33,842 --> 00:00:35,550
After you've signed
in, you'll be brought

14
00:00:35,550 --> 00:00:36,930
to your Atlas dashboard.

15
00:00:36,930 --> 00:00:39,120
Your first organization
will be active

16
00:00:39,120 --> 00:00:40,410
in the upper left-hand corner.

17
00:00:42,940 --> 00:00:46,570
Organizations allow you to
group and define users and teams

18
00:00:46,570 --> 00:00:48,910
and grant them
access to projects.

19
00:00:48,910 --> 00:00:52,000
Projects allow you to define
and organize resources

20
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:53,620
like database clusters.

21
00:00:53,620 --> 00:00:55,750
One common way to
use this feature

22
00:00:55,750 --> 00:00:59,270
is to create separate projects
for development, testing,

23
00:00:59,270 --> 00:01:01,600
and production environments.

24
00:01:01,600 --> 00:01:04,360
Let's go ahead and create
our first Atlas database.

25
00:01:04,360 --> 00:01:06,190
To do so, I'll
click on the Build

26
00:01:06,190 --> 00:01:09,800
a Database button in the
middle of the screen.

27
00:01:09,800 --> 00:01:13,030
This will bring us to our
Deployment Selection screen.

28
00:01:13,030 --> 00:01:14,830
Here, we can see
that we have a choice

29
00:01:14,830 --> 00:01:19,270
between our serverless,
dedicated, and shared tier

30
00:01:19,270 --> 00:01:20,800
options.

31
00:01:20,800 --> 00:01:23,480
Today we're going to be
creating a free tier cluster,

32
00:01:23,480 --> 00:01:25,518
so we'll go ahead and
click on the Create button

33
00:01:25,518 --> 00:01:26,185
to move forward.

34
00:01:29,790 --> 00:01:32,400
After clicking Create, we'll
be brought to the configuration

35
00:01:32,400 --> 00:01:34,920
page for our instance.

36
00:01:34,920 --> 00:01:37,500
First, we'll select the
cloud provider and region

37
00:01:37,500 --> 00:01:39,270
for our instance.

38
00:01:39,270 --> 00:01:42,060
For this particular
case, we'll be using AWS,

39
00:01:42,060 --> 00:01:46,620
but feel free to use GCP or
Azure as your project dictates.

40
00:01:46,620 --> 00:01:48,610
Today I'm in our
New York office,

41
00:01:48,610 --> 00:01:51,330
so I'm going to go ahead
and use the us-east region,

42
00:01:51,330 --> 00:01:54,900
but feel free to use whichever
region is appropriate for you.

43
00:01:54,900 --> 00:01:56,760
Scrolling further
down the page, you

44
00:01:56,760 --> 00:01:59,910
can see that there's even
more configuration settings.

45
00:01:59,910 --> 00:02:03,240
First, let's check
out the cluster here.

46
00:02:03,240 --> 00:02:05,693
Today we're going to be
using the free tier, M0.

47
00:02:05,693 --> 00:02:07,110
But if you ever
feel that you want

48
00:02:07,110 --> 00:02:08,970
to upgrade to one
of our paid tiers,

49
00:02:08,970 --> 00:02:11,830
you can move to the
M2 or M5 quite easily.

50
00:02:11,830 --> 00:02:18,277
You can also move to the M10 or
higher dedicated tier as well.

51
00:02:18,277 --> 00:02:20,110
Next, let's move to our
Additional Settings.

52
00:02:22,730 --> 00:02:24,410
Here, you can see
that we can turn

53
00:02:24,410 --> 00:02:27,530
on the backup setting for
M2 and above clusters.

54
00:02:27,530 --> 00:02:29,600
Again, we'll be on
M0, so we don't need

55
00:02:29,600 --> 00:02:31,950
to worry about turning this on.

56
00:02:31,950 --> 00:02:34,430
Finally, we can customize
the cluster name.

57
00:02:34,430 --> 00:02:36,260
For our example
today, we'll go ahead

58
00:02:36,260 --> 00:02:38,840
and leave the default
cluster name of Cluster0

59
00:02:38,840 --> 00:02:41,000
as our selection.

60
00:02:41,000 --> 00:02:43,475
From here, we'll go ahead
and click on Create Cluster.

61
00:02:47,400 --> 00:02:49,020
After creating our
instance, we'll

62
00:02:49,020 --> 00:02:51,330
be brought to the
Security Quickstart page.

63
00:02:51,330 --> 00:02:56,610
As a default, MongoDB is created
with no users and no IP address

64
00:02:56,610 --> 00:02:59,370
that's allowed to access that
database outside of the Atlas

65
00:02:59,370 --> 00:03:00,880
system itself.

66
00:03:00,880 --> 00:03:02,760
So to get started,
we're going to need

67
00:03:02,760 --> 00:03:04,470
to create an
administrative user,

68
00:03:04,470 --> 00:03:08,800
as well as create an access
point for our IP address.

69
00:03:08,800 --> 00:03:11,580
Let's go ahead and start
with the administrative user.

70
00:03:11,580 --> 00:03:13,500
In the username and
password section,

71
00:03:13,500 --> 00:03:18,270
I'll go ahead and create
an admin and a password.

72
00:03:18,270 --> 00:03:20,640
After doing so, go ahead
and click on Create User

73
00:03:20,640 --> 00:03:24,180
to create this new
administrative user.

74
00:03:24,180 --> 00:03:26,400
As you can see, we've
created our new username

75
00:03:26,400 --> 00:03:28,960
and authentication
type for this user.

76
00:03:28,960 --> 00:03:32,880
Let's go ahead and scroll down
to the IP address section.

77
00:03:32,880 --> 00:03:35,880
As I stated previously,
MongoDB blocks access

78
00:03:35,880 --> 00:03:38,940
from all IP addresses,
except for Atlas itself.

79
00:03:38,940 --> 00:03:41,400
In order to be able
to work with MongoDB

80
00:03:41,400 --> 00:03:43,590
from your local
machine, you'll need

81
00:03:43,590 --> 00:03:47,220
to put your IP address
on the access list.

82
00:03:47,220 --> 00:03:49,560
To do so, you can go
ahead and click on the Add

83
00:03:49,560 --> 00:03:53,100
My Current IP Address button.

84
00:03:53,100 --> 00:03:55,340
Additionally, if you want
to add other IP addresses,

85
00:03:55,340 --> 00:03:58,130
you can use this menu as well.

86
00:03:58,130 --> 00:04:00,170
After adding your
IP address, go ahead

87
00:04:00,170 --> 00:04:02,620
and click on Finish and Close.

88
00:04:02,620 --> 00:04:06,500
Go ahead and click
on Go to Databases.

89
00:04:06,500 --> 00:04:08,630
After finishing with
your security quickstart,

90
00:04:08,630 --> 00:04:11,190
you'll be brought back to the
database deployment screen.

91
00:04:11,190 --> 00:04:14,300
You'll notice that we don't have
data in the database so far.

92
00:04:14,300 --> 00:04:17,329
To add new data, we're going to
go ahead and load a sample data

93
00:04:17,329 --> 00:04:18,050
set.

94
00:04:18,050 --> 00:04:20,720
To do so, go ahead and
click on the ellipsis

95
00:04:20,720 --> 00:04:23,240
next to Browse
Collections, and then

96
00:04:23,240 --> 00:04:24,860
click on Load Sample Dataset.

97
00:04:27,380 --> 00:04:30,100
This will bring up another
modal box in which you can also

98
00:04:30,100 --> 00:04:31,360
click on Load Sample Dataset.

99
00:04:35,450 --> 00:04:37,750
Once you do so, you'll
start loading sample data

100
00:04:37,750 --> 00:04:39,010
into your database.

101
00:04:39,010 --> 00:04:41,800
This process will take a few
minutes, so feel free to go

102
00:04:41,800 --> 00:04:44,230
grab a coffee or a tea, and
just take a short break.

103
00:04:47,050 --> 00:04:50,020
Once Atlas has successfully
finished uploading your sample

104
00:04:50,020 --> 00:04:53,920
data, you'll be able to view
that data in the Data Explorer.

105
00:04:53,920 --> 00:04:57,040
To do so, let's go ahead and
click on Browse Collections.

106
00:05:00,360 --> 00:05:02,190
This will open
Atlas Data Explorer,

107
00:05:02,190 --> 00:05:04,710
which will allow
you to view, filter,

108
00:05:04,710 --> 00:05:07,730
and even modify your data.

109
00:05:07,730 --> 00:05:09,230
On the left-hand
menu, you'll see

110
00:05:09,230 --> 00:05:13,170
a listing of all the databases
available within your cluster.

111
00:05:13,170 --> 00:05:16,550
For example, we've got the
sample airbnb database, as well

112
00:05:16,550 --> 00:05:19,340
as the sample
analytics database.

113
00:05:19,340 --> 00:05:24,180
Let's go ahead and click on
the sample analytics database.

114
00:05:24,180 --> 00:05:25,620
This will then
bring us to a view

115
00:05:25,620 --> 00:05:27,300
in which we can see
all the collections

116
00:05:27,300 --> 00:05:30,040
available within that database.

117
00:05:30,040 --> 00:05:33,320
If we want to view the documents
within a particular collection,

118
00:05:33,320 --> 00:05:35,070
we can click on the
name of the collection

119
00:05:35,070 --> 00:05:38,730
within the left-hand menu or
on the name of that collection

120
00:05:38,730 --> 00:05:40,740
in the view on the right side.

121
00:05:40,740 --> 00:05:43,320
Let's go ahead and take a look
at our accounts collection.

122
00:05:46,230 --> 00:05:48,270
As we can see, we can
view the documents

123
00:05:48,270 --> 00:05:51,580
that exist within the accounts
collection from this view.

124
00:05:51,580 --> 00:05:54,600
What if we want to filter down
to a specific account value,

125
00:05:54,600 --> 00:05:55,620
though?

126
00:05:55,620 --> 00:05:59,550
We can use the filter bar to
specify a particular query

127
00:05:59,550 --> 00:06:02,220
in order to find a
specific document.

128
00:06:02,220 --> 00:06:04,770
For example, what if I
wanted to find a document

129
00:06:04,770 --> 00:06:08,270
by its account_id field?

130
00:06:08,270 --> 00:06:11,510
We can enter a filter
document for an account id

131
00:06:11,510 --> 00:06:15,490
field of 794875.

132
00:06:15,490 --> 00:06:17,230
To apply this
filter to our data,

133
00:06:17,230 --> 00:06:21,300
we'll go ahead and click
on the Apply button.

134
00:06:21,300 --> 00:06:24,180
We can see that this reduces
our view to a single document

135
00:06:24,180 --> 00:06:26,370
within the collection.

136
00:06:26,370 --> 00:06:28,080
Now that you've
learned how to filter

137
00:06:28,080 --> 00:06:30,300
for specific documents
within a collection,

138
00:06:30,300 --> 00:06:32,850
as well as selecting
collections and databases

139
00:06:32,850 --> 00:06:34,980
within your cluster,
you're ready to start

140
00:06:34,980 --> 00:06:38,340
working with the Data
Explorer in Atlas.

141
00:06:38,340 --> 00:06:41,530
Let's quickly recap what we
accomplished in this video.

142
00:06:41,530 --> 00:06:44,580
We set up an Atlas account
and deployed our first Atlas

143
00:06:44,580 --> 00:06:45,510
cluster.

144
00:06:45,510 --> 00:06:49,080
We then set up a database
user and added our IP address

145
00:06:49,080 --> 00:06:51,220
to the IP access list.

146
00:06:51,220 --> 00:06:54,330
Finally, we used the Data
Explorer to load and view

147
00:06:54,330 --> 00:06:56,390
our sample data.

name: Getting Started with MongoDB Atlas, the Developer Data Platform Review

caption.name: Getting Started with MongoDB Atlas, the Developer Data Platform Review
caption.text:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,720
Now, you're familiar with
Atlas, MongoDB's cloud based

2
00:00:03,720 --> 00:00:05,280
developer data platform.

3
00:00:05,280 --> 00:00:08,280
In this unit, you created
a free Atlas account

4
00:00:08,280 --> 00:00:11,640
and deployed a free tier
shared Atlas cluster.

5
00:00:11,640 --> 00:00:15,090
You also created your first
database user and password.

6
00:00:15,090 --> 00:00:18,900
Then, you added your IP
address to the IP access list,

7
00:00:18,900 --> 00:00:21,990
so that you're able to
connect to that cluster.

8
00:00:21,990 --> 00:00:24,840
Finally, you loaded sample
data into the cluster

9
00:00:24,840 --> 00:00:28,690
and viewed documents using a
tool called the Data Explorer.

10
00:00:28,690 --> 00:00:31,540
As a next step, we recommend
familiarizing yourself

11
00:00:31,540 --> 00:00:33,640
with the sample data
in your new cluster.

12
00:00:33,640 --> 00:00:37,150
To do so, use the Atlas Data
Explorer to query collections

13
00:00:37,150 --> 00:00:38,890
and examine documents.

14
00:00:38,890 --> 00:00:43,200
Congratulations on getting
started with MongoDB Atlas.
